descriptions:
Here is a 300-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Medieval Placebo Effect: Hope and Belief in Healthcare in Christian Southern Europe 1100-1500 (MedPlaceboEffect)

This project explores the complex interplay between hope, belief, and healing in medieval Christian Southern Europe (1100-1500). By examining the dynamics between ideas, practices, and organizing structures, we aim to identify the forces that articulated the medieval placebo effect and demonstrate its pervasiveness in medieval healthcare. Our triangular approach will facilitate a rich dialogue between current debates on the placebo effect and medieval perceptions of health and healing.

The project's goals are fourfold: (1) to identify the key factors that shaped the medieval placebo effect, (2) to engage in a timely dialogue between medieval and contemporary understandings of the placebo effect, (3) to illustrate the intricate relationships between ideas, practices, institutions, and networks in medieval healing, and (4) to examine the legacy of medieval health systems and their ongoing negotiation in the 21st century.

The implications of this project are far-reaching, offering insights into the therapeutic elements of medieval healing, the impact of the soul/mind on health, and a foundation for contemporary examinations of healing practices. Moreover, this project addresses pressing challenges in modern healthcare, including distrust in medical services and the difficulties of overcoming placebos in pharmaceutical research.

By shedding light on the medieval roots of the placebo effect, this project will contribute to a deeper understanding of the complex dynamics between healthcare providers, patients, and the healing process. Ultimately, our research will inform the development of more effective and patient-centered healthcare practices, highlighting the significance of hope, belief, and trust in the therapeutic encounter.
